awd_titl_txt: Competing Orders in Quantum Gases with Long-range Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent experiments with trapped ensembles of magnetic atoms and/or polar molecules (molecules that have an electric dipole moment) have achieved the extremely cold temperatures at which quantum mechanical effects abound. Polar atoms and molecules attract and/or repel one another anisotropically (like a pair of magnets), and trapped collections of such particles are expected to display a variety of collective phenomena that are the focus of much current research. Modern experiments with dipolar gases are attempting to provide a controlled environment in which to synthesize, tune, and discover novel phases of polar quantum matter, complementary to the solid, liquid, gas and plasma phases familiar at higher temperatures. While polar systems are expected to display a wide variety of new phenomena, they are not yet well understood and their properties are challenging to predict theoretically. The difficulty arises from their sensitivity: Even small changes in density or temperature can change the phase of the ensemble, and so change observed properties dramatically.  This project is developing new theoretical tools for the analysis of the plurality of phases of ultracold dipolar matter in order to improve our understanding of recent experimental observations. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained through this project in scientific computing, data analysis and visualization in addition to physics. 

The project will develop two innovative many-body techniques for quantum gases with long-range interactions. The first is functional renormalization group for continuum Fermi gases at finite temperatures. It will be used to analyze the many-body instabilities and phase diagrams of dipolar Fermi gases in two-dimensions. The second is tensor network variational ansatz for dipolar atoms or molecules localized in deep optical lattices. It will be benchmarked and adapted to solve effective spin models with competing and long-range exchange interactions. The renormalization group technique will also be applied to study the many-body phases of other quantum gas systems including Rydberg dressed Fermi gases and spin-orbit coupled Fermi gases.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops a full-fledged technique to understand the competing orders in quantum gases of interacting atoms or molecules. Within this context, a major theoretical challenge is to compute and compare the effective interactions, or couplings, for all possible channels on the macroscopic and low-temperature scale from the microscopic, bare interactions between the atoms and molecules. This highly nontrivial problem to connect physics at different scales is well known and solved, at least in principal, by the conceptual framework of renormalization group, where the ?running couplings? change with a varying scale and obey the flow equations. Renormalization flow has been widely used in elementary particle physics, phase transitions, fluid dynamics, and quantum materials. Typically, the number of the running couplings varies from just a few to hundred thousands. To obtain accurate predictions of the phase diagrams of quantum many-body problems, however, one needs to keep track of much more running couplings, each for a given combination of momentum or frequency, or both. Storing such a huge amount of data for each scale and computing their mutual influence at each step of the flow demand specialized, costly computing facilities, and hence limit the wider application of this powerful approach.

The NSF support enables us to tear down some of these technical barriers. By efficient paramertrizing the running couplings (known as vertices in a theoretical framework called functional renormalization group, or FRG) and massively parallelizing the solution of the FRG flow equation on the Graphical Processing Units, an affordable hardware widely used for example in video gaming, machine learning and cryptocurrency mining, we are able to solve the FRG flow equation with over 30 million running couplings within hours instead of weeks. As a result, we achieve an improvement in the momentum or frequency resolution by several orders of magnitude. We have applied the new algorithm to obtain the phase diagrams of Fermi gases with long-range interactions in two dimensions. In particular, we have discovered a novel charge density wave phase for the dipolar Fermi gas, and an f-wave superfluid phase for the Rydberg-dressed Fermi gas. Both phases were not recognized in previous work with crude approximations. These examples illustrate the unique capabilities of FRG as an unbiased, accurate many-body technique for interacting quantum gases. The algorithm innovation may be generalized to study a host of correlated electronic materials.

We have further applied FRG to study the phase diagrams of quantum spin models. The main focus is to sovle quantum spin models with long-range or frustrated interactions, in particular those motivated by quantum gas experiments. We have solved the dipolar Heisenberg model on the square, triangular, and zigzag lattice. In each case, the increased resolution yields fresh insights. For example on the triangular lattice, we have discovered a robust, wide region of quantum paramagnet that lacks conventional magnetic long-range order, and points to a quantum spin liquid. We have systematically benchmarked FRG against other numerical methods including tensor networks and exact diagonalization as well as analytical approaches. These comparisons testify the advantages of FRG due to its unbiased inclusion of all ordering channels, and its increased accuracy.

The project has also stimulated, somewhat unexpectedly, our investigation of the quantum dynamics of spin models and lattice models with nontrivial topological properties inspired by the latest quantum gas experiments. In total, twelve papers are published, including five in Physical Review Letters. Two postdocs were partially supported by this project. They have now become Assistant Professors of Physics. Two undergraduate students were mentored in research, and both of them are now physics PhD students.
